captions.text:
This Dnews episode is brought to you by Domain
Dot Com!

Someone on the DNews team recently posed the
question, “What happens to you if you fall

into a black hole?” As it turns out, horrible,
horrible, awesome, horrible stuff.

Hey there space cadets, I’m Julian, welcome
to another episode of DNews. Today we’re

going to talk about Black Holes, itty bitty
single points in space with so much mass that

even light cannot travel fast enough to escape
their gravitational pull.

Supermassive black holes are at the center
of galaxies and they are enormously massive,

billions times more so than our sun. Stellar
black holes are much smaller and are the remnants
of ex-stars. And you thought your ex was clingy.

Don’t worry though, the closest stellar
black hole to us, Cygnus x-1, is over 6000

light years away and would only really be
dangerous if you got within 14 thousand miles
of it. Phew.

I should say Cygnus is a black hole candidate,
it’s kind of hard to detect black holes

because they swallow light and we can’t
see them directly.

So what happens if you cross that threshold
into a supermassive black hole? You’ll have

gone over the event horizon, and from there
there’s no going back and things get freaky-deaky.

Let’s assume you jumped in head first, because
you’re the adventurous sort. Even though

your head is just a few feet from your….
feet…. the force of gravity is way stronger

on it. At first you wouldn’t notice anything,
but as you get close to the center your head

gets pulled and squished, your whole body
gets stretched out. The technical term is,

“spaghettified.” Nope, that was not one
of my bad jokes. Eventually you’re just

a stream of atoms on your way to join the
singularity. With stellar black holes this

will happen to you long before you cross the
event horizon, so someone could actually watch
you get stretched out.

They’d have to wait a while though. As you
accelerate and get near a massive object,

time for you slows down compared to a stationary
observer that’s much farther away. you wouldn’t

notice it for yourself, but everyone else
would seem to be aging really fast. If someone

wanted to watch you fall into a supermassive
black hole, they couldn’t. As you got closer,

to them you would be moving more and more
slowly. Right at the edge of the horizon you

would seem to stop. You would get dimmer and
turn red as the light waves you reflect gets

pulled and stretched, eventually becoming
too long to see. You would fade to black.

And if movies have taught me anything, that’s
always the best way to end it.

Whoa hey I’m not done yet! I have to tell
you that no domain extension will help you

tell your story like a DOT COM or DOT NET
domain name. And because you watch DNews,

you can get 15% off Domain Dot Com’s domain
names and web hosting when you use the coupon
code DNEWS at checkout.

If you want to learn more about time dilation,
Trace covers that for you in this video right
here.

Would you jump into a black hole? Let us know
in the comments! Please don’t though, because

we like having you around. Thanks for watching
DNews! Ok, NOW you can fade.

title: What Happens Inside A Black Hole?
